sourcesContent:
import React, { useEffect, useRef } from 'react'; import { Box, Container, Tabs, TabList, Tab, TabPanels, TabPanel, Heading, Text, Link, VStack, UnorderedList, ListItem, useColorModeValue, HStack, Select, } from '@chakra-ui/react'; const TabContent = () => { const mapRef = useRef(null); const bgColor = useColorModeValue('white', 'gray.800'); const borderColor = useColorModeValue('gray.200', 'gray.600'); const [selectedMetric, setSelectedMetric] = React.useState('AI Readiness Score'); // Function to get color based on value const getColor = (value, metric) => { if (!value) return '#cccccc'; // Default color for null values let normalizedValue; switch(metric) { case 'AI Readiness Score': normalizedValue = value / 89; // Max score is 89 break; case 'AI Investment (USD Millions)': normalizedValue = value / 328548; // Max investment break; case 'Population (Millions)': normalizedValue = value / 1441; // Max population break; default: normalizedValue = 0; } // Color gradient from red (low) to yellow (medium) to green (high) if (normalizedValue < 0.33) { return '#ff4444'; } else if (normalizedValue < 0.66) { return '#ffbb33'; } else { return '#00C851'; } }; useEffect(() => { const initializeMap = async () => { if (!mapRef.current || !window.L || !window.countryMapData) return; try { // Store ref in variable for cleanup const currentMapRef = mapRef.current; // Initialize map const map = window.L.map(currentMapRef, { center: [20, 0], zoom: 2, minZoom: 2, maxZoom: 10 }); // Add tile layer window.L.tileLayer('https://{s}.tile.openstreetmap.org/{z}/{x}/{y}.png', { attribution: 'Â© OpenStreetMap contributors' }).addTo(map); // Load GeoJSON data const response = await fetch('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/johan/world.geo.json/master/countries.geo.json'); const geoData = await response.json(); // Create the choropleth layer const geojsonLayer = window.L.geoJSON(geoData, { style: (feature) => { const countryData = window.countryMapData.find(c => c.ISO_A3 === feature.properties.iso_a3); return { fillColor: countryData ? getColor(countryData[selectedMetric], selectedMetric) : '#cccccc', weight: 1, opacity: 1, color: 'white', fillOpacity: 0.7 }; }, onEachFeature: (feature, layer) => { const countryData = window.countryMapData.find(c => c.ISO_A3 === feature.properties.iso_a3); if (countryData) { layer.bindPopup(` ${countryData.Country}
AI Readiness Score: ${countryData['AI Readiness Score']}
AI Investment: ${countryData['AI Investment (USD Millions)'] ? '$' + countryData['AI Investment (USD Millions)'].toLocaleString() + 'M' : 'N/A'}
Population: ${countryData['Population (Millions)']}M `); } } }).addTo(map); // Store map instance for cleanup currentMapRef._leaflet = map; currentMapRef._geojsonLayer = geojsonLayer; // Force a resize event setTimeout(() => { map.invalidateSize(); }, 100); } catch (error) { console.error('Error initializing map:', error); } }; if (window.L) { initializeMap(); } return () => { const currentMapRef = mapRef.current; if (currentMapRef && currentMapRef._leaflet) { currentMapRef._leaflet.remove(); } }; }, [selectedMetric]); return ( Homepage Why Global Inclusion Matters Barriers to Inclusive Red Teaming Enabling Participation Domain-Specific Governance Global Coordination References and Resources {/* Homepage Tab */} Bridging the Global AI Divide: Towards Inclusive Safety Artificial intelligence is advancing at breakneck speed, yet its development and benefits are dramatically concentrated. While AI innovation flourishes primarily in a few Global North countries, its impacts reverberate globally, touching populations who often have little influence over its design or deployment. This disconnect creates a stark reality: projections estimate that by 2030, North America, Europe, and China will capture 84% of AI's economic gains, while regions like Africa, Oceania, and the rest of Asia combined may see only 8%. Such trajectories threaten to deepen global inequality, as leading AI nations gain outsized advantages. Furthermore, without inclusive governance, dominant cultural and economic perspectives risk imposing 'one-size-fits-all' AI values and policies ill-suited to diverse local contexts. The data often used to train AI reflects this imbalance. Large language models, typically trained on internet data, underrepresent the world's linguistic diversity; none of the top 34 internet languages are African, and most models cover only about 100 of over 7,000 global languages. This occurs despite Africa being home to nearly 19% of the world's population. Consequently, even advanced AI models exhibit geographic biases favoring high-income regions and can perpetuate harmful stereotypes, such as rating African residents less attractive than Europeans. The stakes are high. This isn't merely about representation in development teams; it's about the real-world consequences when widely used AI systems reflect narrow perspectives. Models trained primarily on Western data can malfunction or misdiagnose when applied elsewhere â for instance, a health AI accurate for European patients has shown significant errors when used with African patients, highlighting how data and design choices impact lives. This project confronts this governance gap by focusing on a critical lever for more democratic AI oversight: **AI red teaming**. By deliberately probing AI systems for vulnerabilities, biases, and unexpected failure modes, we can uncover risks missed by internal teams. Our goal is to identify pathways toward inclusive AI security governance â frameworks that embed global perspectives and promote equity, safety, and accountability across all linguistic and geographic divides. For detailed sources and further reading, please see the References and Resources section. {/* Why Global Inclusion Matters Tab */} Why Global Inclusion Matters Select Metric: Legend Low Medium High No Data Linguistic & Geographic Bias AI systems often perform poorly for languages or communities absent in training data. Independent researchers have found that large language models (trained mostly on English and European data) carry "geographic bias" â for instance, systematically underrating content related to African countries on subjective qualities like "intelligence" or "morality". Generative AI tools also struggle with many low-resource languages, leading to errors and exclusion of non-English speakers. These biases can amplify inequality (e.g. an AI assistant that works well in English but garbles Swahili is far less useful to African users). Health & Safety Risks If AI applications (like medical diagnosis tools) are developed using homogenous data, they can be dangerously unreliable for underrepresented groups. For example, an AI system for skin cancer screening was found to be less accurate on patients with darker skin, because most training images were of light-skinned individuals. Cultural Mismatches & Fairness AI systems often reflect the cultural context of their creators, which can cause problems when deployed globally. Generative AI models have been caught reinforcing stereotypes â for instance, a text-to-image generator trained on Western data might depict Indian festivals in an exotified, caricatured way. {/* Barriers to Inclusive Red Teaming Tab */} Barriers to Inclusive Red Teaming Legal and Regulatory Barriers Many countries have unclear or restrictive laws around AI system testing. This creates legal uncertainty that discourages participation in red teaming efforts. Key issues include: Computer misuse and cybersecurity laws that may criminalize certain testing approaches Intellectual property restrictions limiting access to model details Data protection regulations affecting testing data collection and sharing Export controls on AI technologies that prevent cross-border collaboration Resource and Infrastructure Gaps Many regions face significant resource constraints that limit their ability to participate in AI development and testing: Limited access to computing infrastructure and high-performance hardware Insufficient funding for AI research and testing initiatives Lack of specialized training programs and educational resources Poor internet connectivity and digital infrastructure in some areas Knowledge and Expertise Barriers Technical expertise is often concentrated in a few global hubs, creating challenges for broader participation: Limited access to advanced AI training and education Language barriers in technical documentation and research Brain drain of AI talent to major tech hubs Lack of local mentorship and professional development opportunities {/* Enabling Participation Tab */} Enabling Participation Legal and Policy Solutions Creating an enabling environment for global participation requires addressing legal barriers through: Safe harbor provisions for legitimate AI testing activities Clear guidelines on permissible testing approaches International frameworks for cross-border collaboration Standardized protocols for responsible disclosure Capacity Building Initiatives Supporting the development of local expertise and infrastructure through: Regional AI research and testing centers Training programs and educational partnerships Funding for local AI safety initiatives Technical resource sharing programs Collaborative Networks Building networks to connect global participants: International research partnerships Mentorship programs connecting experts with emerging practitioners Knowledge sharing platforms and communities of practice Regular conferences and workshops focused on inclusive AI safety {/* Domain-Specific Governance Tab */} Domain-Specific Governance Healthcare AI Special considerations for AI systems in healthcare: Patient data privacy and protection requirements Medical device regulations and safety standards Cultural sensitivity in healthcare delivery Access and equity considerations Financial Services Governance frameworks for AI in financial applications: Fair lending and anti-discrimination requirements Risk management and system stability considerations Consumer protection measures Cross-border financial regulations Public Sector Applications Guidelines for government use of AI: Transparency and accountability requirements Public consultation processes Impact assessments for vulnerable populations Democratic oversight mechanisms {/* Global Coordination Tab */} Global Coordination International Frameworks Developing coordinated approaches to AI governance: Multilateral agreements on AI safety standards Shared principles for responsible AI development Cross-border incident response protocols International monitoring and enforcement mechanisms Regional Cooperation Building regional capacity and coordination: Regional AI safety centers and networks Shared research and testing infrastructure Harmonized regulatory approaches Joint capacity building initiatives Stakeholder Engagement Ensuring inclusive participation in governance: Multi-stakeholder dialogue processes Civil society participation mechanisms Industry-government partnerships Academic and research collaboration networks {/* References and Resources Tab */} References and Resources Global AI Governance Frameworks: OECD AI Principles (2019): Multilateral principles for Trustworthy AI, endorsed by 40+ countries. (See also the G20 AI Principles.) UNESCO Recommendation on AI Ethics (2021): Landmark agreement by 193 countries. EU Artificial Intelligence Act: Comprehensive AI law with risk-based approach. (See Public Citizen's comparative analysis.) US Executive Order on Safe AI (2023): U.S. policy directive. China's AI Policy Toolkit: Sectoral regulations (e.g., algorithm regulation). (See Brookings comparison report.) Inclusive AI & Case Studies of Bias: "Large Language Models are Geographically Biased" (Manvi et al. 2024): Research on LLM performance/bias. Penn State/Univ. of Washington Study on Cultural Harm (Venkit et al. 2024): Analysis of generative AI misrepresenting Indian contexts. Gender and Language Bias in AI Translation (e.g., Google Translate case study). Healthcare AI Bias â The Guardian (2021): "AI skin cancer diagnoses risk being less accurate for dark skin". Algorithmic Fairness in Finance â Apple Card Case (e.g., NYT Report 2019). Red Teaming, Safety, and Cybersecurity Analogies: Knight Institute â "A Safe Harbor for AI Red Teaming" (Nov 2023): Argues for legal protections. Open Letter on AI Research Safe Harbor (2024): Text of researcher letter. FAS Report â "Safe Harbor for AI Researchers" (2024): Policy brief on US law. NIST AI Risk Management Framework 1.0 (Jan 2023): Governance guidelines. MITRE "AI Red Teaming: A Case Studies Report": Real examples. Data & Visual Resources: PWC "Sizing the Prize" Report (2017): AI economic impact figures. Stanford AI Index â Global AI Vibrancy Tool: Data on talent, publications, investment. Oxford Insights â Government AI Readiness Index: Ranks countries. World Economic Forum â "The AI Divide" (2023): Stats on North-South gap. GitHub Repositories for Open AI Models: e.g., Hugging Face model hub, Google TensorFlow datasets. Domain-Specific Governance References: IRGC Report "Review of AI Governance Regimes" (2023): Challenges in specific sectors. IAPP Briefing â EU vs. China AI Regulation (2024): Comparison. "Mapping AI in Healthcare" â Nature Public Health (2022): Review of European policies. Financial Stability Board Report on AI in Finance (2020): Regulatory approaches. National AI Strategies Repository (OECD AI Observatory): Collection of documents. Each resource above is linked to encourage policymakers and researchers to explore further. The site is designed to serve as a one-stop hub â effectively a substitute for a traditional research paper â with a rich blend of narrative, data visuals, and references. Whether you're drafting policy, designing an AI system, or studying tech governance, these materials provide a foundation for understanding why inclusive global AI governance is imperative and how we can achieve it together. ); }; export default TabContent;
